block.p: Roses, many roses, to Joseph Horowitz for his two fine articles on Boston's Symphony Hall and on Henry Lee Higginson, who commissioned it and who single-handedly founded and then financed the Boston Symphony Orchestra for so many years [''A Plain Home With a Sense of Pride'' and ''Finding a New Music Director the Old-Fashioned Way,'' Oct. 8].

Roses, many roses, to Joseph Horowitz for his two fine articles on Boston's Symphony Hall and on Henry Lee Higginson, who commissioned it and who single-handedly founded and then financed the Boston Symphony Orchestra for so many years [''A Plain Home With a Sense of Pride'' and ''Finding a New Music Director the Old-Fashioned Way,'' Oct. 8].

A brickbat, however, for what in my opinion is a misreading of John Singer Sargent's portrait of Higginson, of which you reproduced a detail. To my eye his expression is not ''haughty and elevated,'' but rather one of warm, curious amusement at finding himself willy-nilly in such a situation at age 70, the portrait having been commissioned by Harvard and paid for by student subscription as thanks for and commemoration of his having built the Student Union.
The writer is a researcher for the John Singer Sargent Catalogue Raisonne Project.
